docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Physicians and medical clinics are not the only health care providers feeling financial pressures because of managed care (Week in Review, Aug. 30). Teaching hospitals, traditionally the safety-net providers for the uninsured, continue to report increasing losses due to unsponsored care.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Health-Care Road Trip'' (column, Aug. 31), Bob Herbert doesn't mention that of the 8 to 11 million uninsured children in America, 4.7 million are eligible for but not enrolled in Medicaid. Public health advocates know that the mere existence of programs is not enough to prevent disease. Government, business and community groups must be more active in locating the families of children without health insurance. The media and community groups should make greater efforts to inform parents of eligibility requirements.

headline.main: Insurance Alone Won't Make Children Healthier

docs.lead_paragraph: LABOR DAY is still seen largely as a blue-collar, big-shoulders kind of holiday, even though the overwhelming majority of its celebrants are largely disassociated from the principles of the organized work force. According to the Labor Department, there were slightly more than 16 million union members at work in the country last year, about 14.1 percent of all workers. The proportion of union workers has been steadily declining since 1953, when it was nearly 27 percent.

headline.main: A Labor-Friendly Fund Helps to Channel the Power of Unions

docs.abstract: MFS Union Standard Equity fund will invest only in companies that meet certain criteria of labor friendliness; MFS Investment Management created fund initially for public and labor union pension plans, but it has since been opened to retail investors; Mitchell Dynan, manager, comments; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Bob Herbert (column, Aug. 31) notes that more than 20 million young Americans have inadequate health-care access and some 11 million are uninsured. In New York City, children in poor neighborhoods experience dangerously low immunization rates, increasing susceptibility to vaccine-preventable illnesses like polio and measles. Given this obvious health crisis, why is New York City devoting $2.7 million to ''improve'' its water quality when no safety hazard exists?

headline.main: Insurance Alone Won't Make Children Healthier

docs.lead_paragraph: When the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company built Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village in the mid-1940's, they created a self-contained community of 25,000 people, many of them families headed by returning war veterans. Stores ringed the red-brick complex and physicians, dentists and eye doctors occupied many of the buildings' ground-floor spaces. But during the last year, Met Life has been quietly informing tenants of professional suites that they will have to go elsewhere. Many of the two dozen podiatrists, ophthalmologists and orthodontists who rent space in the project's 56 residential buildings have either been denied lease renewals or given one-year extensions.

headline.main: Landlord Tells Doctors in the House It's Time to Go

docs.abstract: Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, owner of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, is forcing out the doctors, dentists and other professionals who have occupied the ground-floor medical suites since the 1940's (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''SICK people should always have medevac insurance,'' in the view of Dr. John W. Aldis, a medical officer in the United States Embassy in Beijing. ''There was the man with leukemia who came to China for a miracle cure he heard about,'' Dr. Aldis reported to his fellow health professionals. ''He got insurance to ship his body back in the unlikely event that the treatment failed but declined the regular medevac insurance. After a few weeks of one medical disaster after another, he finally decided he wanted to return home. Of course, by that time his condition was so deteriorated that there was no possible way for the regular airlines to take him. His 'dying wish' to die at home had to be denied.''
docs.abstract: Practical Traveler column on advice that travelers, especially older people, take out medevac policies to get them back home in medical emergencies (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''The Uninsured Find Fewer Doctors in the House'' (Week in Review, Aug. 30) inaccurately blamed managed care for the demise of the health-care safety net. Managed care has succeeded in eliminating many of the inefficient cross-subsidies that supported the safety net simply by shifting costs to other parts of the health care system. These included balance billing -- when doctors charged wealthy Medicare patients the difference between Medicare's reimbursement for a procedure and their standard fee, and then applied the difference to charity work.

headline.main: Insurance Alone Won't Make Children Healthier

docs.lead_paragraph: Well, I did it playing soccer at the age of 42, but before you start muttering, Geez, what did she expect, let me tell you some of the other ways overenergetic baby boomers do it: playing tennis, playing basketball, playing volleyball, playing softball, downhill skiing, diving sideways for a Frisbee at the beach or making one rapid feint in the spur-of-the-moment touch-football game that seemed like such a good idea until the part with the writhing and the screaming and the panicky-faced people running for ice and a medic. Myself, I don't remember that part precisely. I do remember opening my eyes and perceiving that I was on my back. The central midfielder was looking down at me with an expression that alarmed me as much as the pain did. I remember thinking: Oh, no. This is big.

headline.main: How the Knee Became the Back

docs.abstract: Cynthia Gorney article on knee injury she suffered from playing soccer at age 42, and reconstruction surgery that followed; photos; diagram; reports that similar injuries are becoming far more common in people who are not professional athletes, but who are much more active in their adult years; warns of particular risk to women (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Lynne Candace Brady, a speech-language pathologist at the Spaulding Rehabilitation Hospital in Boston, was married yesterday to Dr. Andrew Jay Wagner, a resident in internal medicine at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. The Rev. Elizabeth Smith, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Pen Ryn Mansion in Bensalem, Pa. Mrs. Wagner, 31, graduated from St. Louis University, from which she also received a master's degree in speech-language pathology. She was a fellow at the MacLean Center of Clinical Medical Ethics at the University of Chicago in 1996 and 1997. Her parents, Mary Ellen and James Brady, live in Kansas City, Mo., where her father is an independent insurance agent and her mother is a child welfare advocate for the Missouri child support enforcement division. Dr. Wagner, 30, graduated from Swarthmore College and received M.D. and Ph.D. degrees in biochemistry and molecular biology from Chicago. He is a son of Emily Wagner and Dr. Charles Wagner of Rydal, Pa. His mother is the assistant head of the middle school at Germantown Academy in Fort Washington, Pa., and teaches French there. His father, a gastroenterologist, is the chief medical officer of the Holy Redeemer Health System in Huntingdon Valley, Pa.
